content: How can I help you today?
I’ve just been having a hard time sleeping lately. My partner suggested I talk to someone about it, but I’m not sure if this will even help to be honest.

Thanks for sharing that. It sounds like the difficulty sleeping has been weighing on you, and it’s great that you’re considering different ways to address it. What has this struggle been like for you?

Well, it’s been frustrating. I lie in bed with so many thoughts racing through my head, mostly about work. I’m worried about possibly getting fired, and I can’t seem to shut my brain off. It’s like a never-ending cycle.

That does sound frustrating—lying there with your thoughts running nonstop, especially about something as stressful as work. It takes a lot to keep going when you're carrying that kind of worry. How have you been managing it so far?
I’ve been trying to distract myself by scrolling on my phone, but I know it’s not really helping. If anything, it just adds more stuff to think about, but it’s really hard to stop.

It sounds like you’ve been trying to find ways to cope, even though scrolling on your phone doesn’t bring much relief and may even make things harder. It’s not easy to break habits like that, especially when your mind feels so full. What do you wish could happen when you’re lying there at night?
Honestly, I just wish I could shut my brain off and get some real rest. I want to wake up feeling like I can handle the day instead of feeling more exhausted, but I don’t know how to get there.

Wanting to wake up feeling refreshed and ready for the day sounds like a real longing for relief, especially when you’ve been stuck in this exhausting cycle. Finding rest that restores you seems really important to you. What do you think might help you move closer to that?
Maybe finding a way to calm my thoughts before bed, but I honestly don’t even know where to start with that. My mind just feels too loud sometimes, and I’m not sure what would actually work.

It sounds like quieting your thoughts feels like such a big challenge right now, especially when they’re so overwhelming. Still, you’re considering ways that might help, even though you’re unsure where to begin. What do you think has held you back from trying anything in the past?

I guess it’s partly because I’m so tired by the time I get to bed that I don’t want to put energy into trying something new. And at the same time, I worry it won’t even work, so what’s the point? It just feels easier to reach for my phone instead.

It sounds like the exhaustion makes it harder to take that first step, and there’s the uncertainty about whether it would even help—which makes it feel safer to stick with what’s familiar, even if it’s not giving you the peace you want. That’s a tough spot to be in. What makes you think a change might still be worth considering?

I guess part of me knows that what I’m doing now isn’t working, and I can’t keep going on like this forever. Plus, I don’t want the stress and lack of sleep to start affecting my family even more than it already is. I just don’t know if I have the energy to stick with anything.

You're recognizing that what’s happening now isn’t sustainable, and you’re thinking about the impact on your family and yourself, even while you're doubting whether you can follow through. That shows how much you care and want things to improve, even though it feels hard. What do you think could make trying something new feel more manageable for you?
Maybe if it were something small to start with, like something that doesn’t feel overwhelming or take too much energy. I just need something that feels doable, even on the worst nights.

Starting small sounds like a thoughtful way to ease into change without adding pressure. You’re prioritizing what feels achievable, even on your hardest nights, and that’s an important step forward. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about before exploring possibilities for taking that first step?
No, I think I’m okay to end the conversation now. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
